questions.question: What is the correct syntax for declaring a function in C?
questions.hint: Function declarations end with semicolon in C.
questions.explanation: Correct C function declaration syntax: return_type function_name(parameter_types); The declaration specifies what the function does without implementing it.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a C format specifier?
questions.explanation: %t is not a standard C format specifier. Valid specifiers include %d (int), %f (float), %s (string), %c (char), %x (hex), %o (octal).

questions.question: What is the syntax for binary file writing in C?
questions.hint: Binary mode adds 'b' to the mode string.
questions.explanation: Correct syntax for binary write mode: fopen("filename", "wb") where 'w' means write and 'b' means binary.

questions.question: Can two functions in C++ have the same name and parameters?
questions.explanation: Functions can have same name and parameters if in different namespaces, due to namespace scope separation.

questions.question: Which operators can be overloaded in C++?
questions.hint: Most operators can be overloaded in C++.
questions.explanation: All arithmetic, comparison, and logical operators can be overloaded in C++, except for ::, ., .*, and ?:

questions.question: What is Inheritance in OOP?
questions.hint: Creating new classes based on existing ones.
questions.explanation: Inheritance allows creating new classes from existing classes, inheriting properties and methods.

questions.question: Virtual functions are accessed through?
questions.explanation: Virtual functions are accessed through object pointers or references to enable polymorphic behavior.

questions.question: How is exception handling implemented in C++?
questions.explanation: C++ exception handling uses try-catch-throw mechanism where try contains code that might throw, catch handles thrown exceptions.

questions.question: What is purpose of 'override' keyword in C++?
options: Indicate function is override of virtual function
questions.correct_answer: Indicate function is override of virtual function
questions.explanation: 'override' keyword explicitly declares that a function overrides a virtual base class function, catching errors at compile time.

questions.question: What is single-level inheritance?
questions.explanation: Single-level inheritance occurs when a derived class inherits from exactly one base class.

questions.question: What software model represents behavior and interactions?
questions.explanation: Use case diagrams represent system behavior and interactions between system and external actors.

questions.question: Which C function finds current position in file?
questions.explanation: ftell() returns the current position of the file pointer in the file.

questions.question: What does fwrite(str, strlen(str) + 1, 1, filePointer) do?
questions.explanation: strlen(str) + 1 includes null character, so fwrite writes entire string with null terminator.

questions.question: What SQL command removes content without changing structure?
questions.explanation: DELETE removes rows while preserving table structure. DROP removes entire table. TRUNCATE removes all rows but faster than DELETE.

questions.question: What does software quality management consist of?
questions.explanation: Software Quality Management includes SQA (Software Quality Assurance) and SQM (Software Quality Management).

questions.question: What is compiler vs interpreter difference?
options: Compiler line-by-line, interpreter all at once
Compiler all at once, interpreter line-by-line
questions.correct_answer: Compiler all at once, interpreter line-by-line
questions.explanation: Compiler translates entire program before execution. Interpreter translates and executes line by line during runtime.

questions.question: What is default access specifier for C++ class members?
questions.explanation: By default, all class members in C++ are private unless declared as public or protected.

questions.question: What OOP concept allows different classes to be treated as common base?
questions.explanation: Polymorphism allows objects of different classes to be treated through common base class interface.

questions.question: In indexed addressing MOV 5(R1), LOC, effective address is?
questions.explanation: Indexed addressing: EA = displacement + [register]. Here: EA = 5 + [R1]

questions.question: What provides fastest data access?
questions.explanation: Registers provide fastest access because they're on the CPU with zero latency.

questions.question: What is throw keyword in C++?
questions.explanation: throw keyword throws an exception, transferring control to nearest catch block.

questions.question: What namespace feature does C++ provide?
questions.explanation: Namespaces provide scope for identifiers and can be used throughout the program.

questions.question: How to alias namespace in C++?
questions.explanation: Correct syntax: namespace new_name = existing_namespace; creates alias.

questions.question: What must be overloaded as member function in C++?
questions.explanation: =, [], and () operators must be overloaded as member functions, not global functions.

questions.question: What is static variable in C++?
questions.explanation: Static variables retain their value between function calls and are initialized only once.

questions.question: What is main function of control unit?
questions.explanation: Control unit's primary function is fetching instructions from memory during the fetch phase of execution cycle.

questions.question: What is fetch-decode-execute cycle order?
questions.explanation: Correct order: Fetch instruction → Decode instruction → Execute instruction → Store result

questions.question: Which memory level has shortest latency?
questions.explanation: Cache memory has shortest latency because it's on-chip and closest to the CPU.

questions.question: What manages virtual memory in computer?
questions.explanation: Operating system manages virtual memory by maintaining page tables and handling page faults.

questions.question: What addressing mode accesses stack?
questions.explanation: Indirect addressing mode is used for stack access through stack pointer register.

questions.question: What level of memory is fastest?
questions.explanation: L1 cache is fastest memory level because it's on-chip and has lowest latency.

questions.question: Which cache level is available?
questions.hint: Modern CPUs have multiple cache levels.
questions.explanation: Modern processors typically have L1, L2, and L3 caches for hierarchical memory access.

questions.question: What is microinstruction in indirect control?
questions.explanation: In indirect microinstruction, next microinstruction address is stored in memory location.

questions.question: Which connector connects external devices?
questions.explanation: USB is most common connector for connecting external devices to computers.

questions.question: What is multiplication operation result size?
questions.explanation: Multiplying two n-bit numbers produces result of up to 2n bits.

questions.question: What is page translation device in CPU?
questions.explanation: Page table in memory translates virtual addresses to physical addresses for virtual memory management.

questions.question: What is pipeline having multiple stages?
questions.explanation: Instruction pipeline divides instruction processing into multiple stages for parallel execution.

questions.question: What component typically controls cursor movement?
questions.explanation: Mouse is standard peripheral for cursor control in graphical interfaces.

questions.question: What is firmware in embedded system?
questions.explanation: Firmware is software stored in read-only memory (ROM) that controls embedded system behavior.

questions.question: What port is most pin-efficient communication method?
questions.explanation: Serial port is most pin-efficient, requiring only 2-3 pins versus many for parallel.

questions.question: What is BIOS primarily used for?
questions.explanation: BIOS performs system initialization and bootstrap operations during computer startup.

questions.question: What is preemption in real-time system?
questions.explanation: Preemption is ability to interrupt currently executing task and switch to higher priority task.

questions.question: What is purpose of RTOS?
questions.explanation: Real-time operating system manages system resources and scheduling to meet time constraints.

questions.question: What is memory controller function?
questions.explanation: Memory controller manages all memory read/write operations and controls memory bus.

questions.question: What is cache coherence purpose?
questions.explanation: Cache coherence ensures consistency when multiple caches contain same data in multiprocessor systems.
